content: The Act may be cited as the "Judicial District of the Virgin Islands Act of 2005" and establishes the District Court of the Virgin Islands as an Article III court. The "Judicial District of the Virgin Islands Act of 2005" establishes the Virgin Islands as one judicial district with two divisions: the Saint Croix Division and the Saint Thomas and Saint John Division. Court sessions will be held at Christiansted for the Saint Croix Division and at Charlotte-Amalie for the Saint Thomas and Saint John Division. The number of judges in the Virgin Islands is amended to 2. Sections 25, 26, and 27 of the Revised Organic Act of the Virgin Islands are repealed, and amendments are made to the Bill of Rights. The jurisdiction of local courts in the Virgin Islands is amended under the Revised Organic Act, allowing offenses to be prosecuted by information except those required to be prosecuted by indictment by grand jury. The jurisdiction of local courts in the Virgin Islands is amended under the Revised Organic Act to allow offenses to be prosecuted by information, except those required to be prosecuted by indictment by grand jury. SEC. 21 addresses the jurisdiction of courts in the Virgin Islands. The judicial power in the Virgin Islands is vested in local courts established by local law, with jurisdiction over causes not under exclusive jurisdiction of US courts. Rules for practice, procedure, and qualifications of judges are governed by local law or court rules. Jurisdiction over criminal matters and income tax is addressed in the Revised Organic Act. Section 22 of the Revised Organic Act of the Virgin Islands (48 U.S.C. 1612) is being amended. Section 22 of the Revised Organic Act of the Virgin Islands (48 U.S.C. 1612) is being amended to address jurisdiction over income tax. The United States District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands has exclusive jurisdiction over criminal and civil proceedings related to income tax laws in the Virgin Islands. Offenses under the income tax laws can be prosecuted by the government of the Virgin Islands in the District Court without the consent of the United States attorney for the Virgin Islands. The United States District Court for the Virgin Islands has exclusive jurisdiction over income tax laws, allowing the government of the Virgin Islands to prosecute offenses without the consent of the United States attorney. Relations between United States courts and local courts are addressed in the Revised Organic Act. Relations between United States courts and local courts are addressed in the Revised Organic Act, specifically in Section 23. The relations between United States courts and local courts are governed by the laws of the United States, including the jurisdiction of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit to review final decisions of the highest court of the Virgin Islands for the first 15 years following the establishment of the appellate court authorized by section 21(a) of the Act. The Judicial Council of the Third Circuit will report to Congress every 5 years on whether the appellate court in the Virgin Islands has developed enough institutional traditions for direct review by the Supreme Court. The US Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit has jurisdiction to create rules for this purpose. The Revised Organic Act of the Virgin Islands is amended to replace "District Court of the Virgin Islands" with "United States District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands." Section 24 is also amended to allow for the assignment of additional judges to the court. Section 24 of the Revised Organic Act of the Virgin Islands is amended to allow for the assignment of additional judges to the United States District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands. The Revised Organic Act of the Virgin Islands is amended to allow for the temporary assignment of additional judges to the United States District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands by the Chief Judge of the Third Judicial Circuit or the Chief Justice of the United States with consent. The District of the Virgin Islands requires all pleadings and proceedings to be conducted in English. Pending cases in the District Court of the Virgin Islands can be pursued in the United States District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands, the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, and the United States Supreme Court. Existing officers of the court in the Virgin Islands can continue in their roles until a successor is appointed under title 28, United States Code. SEC. 3. TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The calculation of service for a retiring district court judge includes service in the District Court of the Virgin Islands before the effective date of the Act. Existing retirees' rights are not affected by the Act. The definition of courts in title 28, United States Code is amended to exclude the District Court of the Virgin Islands. ADDITIONAL REFERENCES: Any mention of the District Court of the Virgin Islands in laws will now refer to the United States District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands. SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE: This Act and its changes will take effect 90 days after enactment.
